awd_titl_txt: Intellectual Migration Dynamics Between China and the U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to understand the migration dynamics of highly educated migrants.  Using the "intellectual migration" framework and empirically connecting China and the United States, the research aims to understand the who, why, and where, of intellectual migration and examine how country-specific policies impact intellectual migration. This project will contribute to ideas about the movement of people between countries and what motivates them, and adds a geographical dimension to the understanding of the migration of the highly educated. This project is significant as China has been a main source of international students and foreign-born professionals in the U.S. in recent decades. A better understanding of the dynamics of these highly-educated migrants can inform policies that facilitate mutually beneficial intellectual migration. Findings will help US national, local and institutional leaders to retain/build a diverse US-trained workforce of different backgrounds and in different fields which enhances local, regional, and national economic development. 

This project will be conducted by an interdisciplinary and international team of researchers and employs a multi-level and multi-methods approach, integrating surveys and in-depth interviews with secondary data analysis and GIS mapping to study a cross-sectional sample of three groups of migrants: pre-international-migration students in China, China-born international students and faculty in the U.S., and China-born and US-trained faculty and professional returnees in China. Results from this study are expected to advance theory on mobility and transnationalism, and will add a geographical dimension to the understanding of the migration of the highly educated.  Findings will facilitate further research to conduct comparative analysis with other major highly-educated migrant sending and receiving locations in the future.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded project, entitled Intellectual Migration: the Changing US-China Dynamics, aims

  1. to develop the intellectual migration framework to analyze the spectrum of highly educated and highly-skilled migrants across space and over time;
  2. to understand the WHO, WHY and WHERE of intellectual migration and examine HOW global geopolitical structural changes and country- or local-specific policies may affect intellectual migration;
  3. to contribute to the theories on mobility and transnationalism,
  4. to add an important geographical dimension to the internal and international migrations of the highly educated, and
  5. to comprehend the achievements and difficulties faced by seasoned and emerging talent in both countries to advance transnational education, research and collaboration.

This evident-based project is to contribute to the US immigration debate to better US economy and society.  

During the 5-year project period, the research team, in collaboration with another project team funded by the Social Science and Humanity Research Council of Canada,

  • completed the originally planned and revised project activities,
  • published a total of one journal special issue, eight journal articles and two book chapters; with another journal special issue containing four more project-related articles are in the final stage of preparation; and
  • delivered seven invited full lectures, invited (six) and regular (14) conference presentations to local, national or international audiences.

Our key project research findings and advancements include:

1. Empirical findings the rising knowledge-based economy has created a higher-than-ever demand for skilled workers with college degrees and professional trainings, the focus of our research:

  • We compared domestic students in China and Chinese international students in North America (at both the undergraduate and graduate levels) to highlight their aspirations and capabilities on mobility outcomes, and the implications for social equality. We learned that (1) Chinese students? capability to study abroad largely reflects social inequality and intergenerational inheritance, and (2) once abroad, Chinese international students rely more on their own agency to acquire intellectual capital for future mobility, underscoring that an overseas study can serves as a mediating process for those from less privileged backgrounds.
  • On Chinese academics, we found most are active in transnational networking in order to advance their career, but their stay in North America or return to China is largely determined by where they can maximize their full potentials. Any policies instituted by their home or destination country that are perceived as welcoming or hostile also impact their decisions.
  • We expanded our initial project goals to incude analyzing skilled American professionals in China, and we found that a strong knowledge-based economy and a welcoming socio-cultural environment in an emerging country can serve as  magnets in attracting international talent.

2. Intellectual merits the intellectual migration framework articulates the underlying key concepts?intellectual capital, intellectual nodes, intellectual gateways, intellectual peripheries?and the role they play in individuals? spatial and social mobilities, and in connecting internal migration with international migration. It contends that higher-education and highly-skilled migrants acquire, upgrade and utilize intellectual capital for upward career and social mobility. By connecting with the history of science, management, and the geography of innovation literatures, the intellectual migration framework offers an interdisciplinary perspective on migration and mobility studies on the one hand, and urban development, racial/social justice and global equality studies on the other. It presents an analytical tool to address issues like the (un)certainty of engaging in intellectual migration, the agency-structure dynamics behind migration decisions and the value of intellectual capital in the migration process.

3. Broader impacts beyond individual accumulation and utilization of intellectual capital to fulfill career and life goals, structural factors such as changing geopolitics and the onset of the recent COVID-19 pandemic have profound impacts on transnational intellectual migration. For example, the ?tough on China? policies have adversely affected intellectual migration between the U.S. and China. While it is important to protect national security and economic interest, we believe domestic and international policy formation need be just and fair toward all.
